verses.text: Why do the nations rage, and the peoples plot in vain?
verses.comment: This opening points to humanity's rebellion against God's rule. Quoted in Acts 4, identifying Jesus as fulfilling this prophecy.

verses.text: The kings of the earth take their stand, and the rulers gather together against the LORD and against his Anointed:
verses.comment: ‘Anointed’ is the Hebrew word ‘Messiah’; in Greek, ‘Christos.’ This is understood as a prophecy of Christ (the Messiah), and fulfilled in the gathering against Jesus before his crucifixion.

verses.text: "Let us burst their bonds apart and cast away their cords from us!"
verses.comment: The nations desire to throw off God’s authority, echoing the perennial human temptation to deny God’s rightful rule.

verses.text: He who sits in the heavens laughs; the Lord ridicules them.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty and power are unshaken by human rebellion.

verses.text: Then he speaks to them in his wrath, and terrifies them in his fury, saying:
verses.comment: God’s response includes both warning and just judgment.

verses.text: "I have installed my King on Zion, my holy mountain."
verses.comment: Zion symbolically refers to Jerusalem and spiritually to the Church founded by Christ (see Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: "I will declare the decree: The LORD said to me, 'You are my Son; today I have begotten you.'"
verses.comment: A direct reference to the divine Sonship of the Messiah, fulfilled in Christ at his Baptism and Transfiguration (see Mt 3:17, 17:5). Key christological verse, foundational in both New Testament citations and Church doctrine.

verses.text: "Ask of me, and I will give you the nations as your inheritance, and the ends of the earth as your possession."
verses.comment: A promise to the Messiah of universal kingship. The Catholic Church sees in this the foundation for Christ’s call to bring all nations to himself, continued through the apostolic mission.

verses.text: "You shall break them with a rod of iron; you shall shatter them like a potter's vessel."
verses.comment: Quoted in Revelation 2 about Christ. Represents the Messiah’s authority, exercising both justice and mercy. The imagery is consistent with the authority given to Christ’s Church (see Mt 16:18-19).

verses.text: Now therefore, O kings, be wise; be warned, O rulers of the earth.
verses.comment: A call to all human authorities to submit to God’s rule and wisdom.

verses.text: Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling.
verses.comment: True worship includes awe and reverence before God. The note of joy and trembling reflects the experience of communion with God, foundational in both private devotion and liturgical worship (as practiced in Catholic tradition).

verses.text: Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and you perish in the way, for his wrath is quickly kindled. Blessed are all who take refuge in him.
verses.comment: ‘Kiss the Son’ indicates reverence, submission, and adoration—echoed in the Catholic practice of honoring Christ. The Catholic liturgy’s gestures of reverence, such as venerating altars and icons, are ancient traditions connecting to this idea. Taking refuge in Christ is at the core of salvation, emphasizing grace received through faith and sacramental life.
